instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U5000: What is U5000? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in macbooks from 2013-2015.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> get to s0 state but no cpu vcore
threads.message: I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, ive gotten it to get to an s0 state now but im missing cpu vcore and i have a .056 in diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>, What are the chances my cpu is fucked

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> get to s0 state but no cpu vcore
threads.message: Resistance to GND on Vcore? <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> present? History?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> get to s0 state but no cpu vcore
threads.message: 93 ohms to ground. 302mv on all sys, pickle juice was spilled on it, there is come corrosion around <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> get to s0 state but no cpu vcore
threads.message: Well, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> should of course be high. Find the missing rail....

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> get to s0 state but no cpu vcore
threads.message: so i think i have have short to ground on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> i get 116 ohm to ground on that line

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> get to s0 state but no cpu vcore
threads.message: i removed both <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>, <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>, and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and i still get 116 ohm to ground on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> only thing left on that line is <CHIP>U5000</CHIP>...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> get to s0 state but no cpu vcore
threads.message: nevermind, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> also goes to <CHIP>U1845</CHIP> which was corroded to hell, replaced it and now were all good computer boots no issues
